title: Twitter reacts to Patriots' win over Broncos, returning to Super Bowl
description: James White, Jason McCourty, Stephon Gilmore and others react to the Patriots' AFC Championship win over the Broncos.
fullText:
The New England Patriots are headed to Super Bowl LX after defeating the Denver Broncos by a 10-7 score in the AFC Championship Game on Sunday.

Defense ruled the day in a low-scoring, messy game for both teams. It was tough to move the ball downfield for both offenses with the snow pouring from the sky at Empower Field at Mile High Stadium. The Patriots recorded only 206 total yards of offense, while the Broncos only mustered 181 total yards.

The rushing attack was a major factor for the Patriots on a day when throwing the ball in the elements proved difficult. They recorded 141 yards on the ground, including a six-yard rushing touchdown from Patriots quarterback Drake Maye.

The difference in the game ended up being the turnover the Patriots forced on Broncos quarterback Jarrett Stidham, who fumbled a backwards pass while being hit by linebacker Christian Elliss. That play put the Patriots in the red zone and set up the touchdown run by Maye.

Overall, Maye went 10-of-21 passing for 86 yards, along with rushing 10 times for 65 yards and one touchdown. Rhamondre Stevenson had 25 carries for 71 yards to help punch New England's ticket to the Super Bowl.

Here is how fans reacted on social media to the Patriots' win:

title: AFC championship: The 10 best photos from the Patriots' snowy win over the Broncos to reach the Super Bowl

fullText:
Drake Maye and the New England Patriots had to survive the elements to reach Super Bowl LX on Sunday.

The Patriots beat the Denver Broncos 10-7 in the AFC championship game on Sunday to reach their first Super Bowl since the Tom Brady era ended. While things were clear in the first half of the contest at Empower Field at Mile High, a snow storm quickly blew in and completely changed the game. title: Mike Vrabel Will Make Unique History If Patriots Win Super Bowl
description: The New England Patriots are headed to the Super Bowl after their 10-7 win over the Denver Broncos in the AFC Championship Game. With the Patriots reaching the big game, Mike Vrabel not only joins an exclusive club, but also has the chance to make some more history as well. Vrabel will be the second [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
The New England Patriots are headed to the Super Bowl after their 10-7 win over the Denver Broncos in the AFC Championship Game.

With the Patriots reaching the big game, Mike Vrabel not only joins an exclusive club, but also has the chance to make some more history as well. Vrabel will be the second person ever to coach and play in a Super Bowl for the same team.

Vrabel joins Gary Kubiak as the only coach who has reached a Super Bowl with the same team as both a coach and a player. If the Patriots win the Super Bowl, Vrabel will be the first person in history to win a Super Bowl as a coach and player for the same franchise.

Tom Flores, Mike Ditka, Tony Dungy and Doug Pederson are the only people to win a Super Bowl as both a player and a coach, but none did so with the same team. Vrabel won three Super Bowls as a player, and in his first year as a head coach with the Patriots, he has taken them to the Super Bowl.

Vrabel is the eighth coach in history to lead a team to the Super Bowl in his first year with the team. He joins Kubiak, Jim Caldwell, Jon Gruden, Bill Callahan, George Seifert, Red Miller and Don McCafferty.

The Patriots were 4-13 last season, and in Vrabel‚Äôs first season, they went 14-3, won the AFC East and clinched the No. 2 seed in the AFC. It is the Patriots‚Äô first Super Bowl appearance since the 2018 season, when they defeated the Los Angeles Rams.

Vrabel is a finalist for Coach of the Year. He won Coach of the Year in 2021 with the Tennessee Titans. He went to the AFC Championship in 2019 with the Titans. As a player, he was a Pro Bowler and First-Team All-Pro.

Although Vrabel was a linebacker, he caught 12 touchdowns in his career in the regular season and playoffs combined. He also had 66 sacks, 24 forced fumbles and 851 tackles between the regular season and playoffs in his career.

Patriots‚Äô Drake Maye Joins Elite QB Company After Beating Broncos

title: WATCH: Pro Oregon Duck CB Christian Gonzalez makes game-winning INT
description: Former Oregon Ducks star cornerback Christian Gonzalez sealed the New England Patriots' spot in the Super Bowl with a game-ending interception.
fullText:
While one season ends for a professional Oregon Duck, another season continues.

Of course, former Oregon QB Bo Nix saw his season come to an end with the Denver Broncos a week ago, after news of his broken ankle suffered in overtime against the Buffalo Bills, but it was fellow former Oregon star Christian Gonzalez, a New England Patriots cornerback, who officially ended things for the Broncos on Sunday afternoon with a game-sealing interception.

With the Patriots leading 10-7 late in the fourth quarter of a low-scoring game being played in a Denver blizzard, Gonzalez dropped into coverage and baited backup Broncos quarterback Jarrett Stidham into an ill-advised throw, which he intercepted to seal the New England win.

GONZO!!!

Huge interception late in the AFC Championship Game! ü¶Ü #ProDucks x @chrisgonzo28 pic.twitter.com/BLqVRknNF1

‚Äî Oregon Football (@oregonfootball) January 25, 2026

The Patriots will now go on to the Super Bowl, where they will face either the Seattle Seahawks or Los Angeles Rams. Against either squad, Gonzalez is bound to be a major part of the gameplay, being asked to cover either Davante Adams or Puka Nakua (Los Angeles) or Jaxson Smith-Njigba (Seattle).

Despite missing the first few games of the year, Gonzalez has proven himself as one of the best cornerback sin the league this season.

title: Patriots DT Milton Williams takes shot at Broncos‚Äô offensive line after AFC championship win: ‚ÄòKiss my a‚Äî'
description: The Patriots' big-ticket free agent had three words for the Broncos' offensive line after advancing to Super Bowl 60.
fullText:
Patriots DT Milton Williams takes shot at Broncos‚Äô offensive line after AFC championship win: ‚ÄòKiss my a‚Äî' originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

A year after Milton Williams sacked Patrick Mahomes twice in the Super Bowl, he is heading back.

Williams and the New England Patriots punched their ticket to Super Bowl 60 on Sunday, and the high-priced free agent addition is someone the team can lean on as it prepares to navigate a long two weeks before the big game.

After the Patriots won a low-scoring AFC championship game over the Denver Broncos, Williams had a parting shot for a Broncos offensive line some consider to be the best in the NFL.

Here's a look at what Williams said as he left the field in Denver.

Patriots punch ticket to Super Bowl for first time in six years

Drake Maye's rushing attack makes up for lackluster passing game

Jarrett Stidham¬†can't overcome snowy Denver conditions in AFC championship loss

After the Patriots finished off a snowy 10-7 win over the Broncos, Williams took a shot at Denver's offensive line. "No. 1 offensive line can kiss my a‚Äî," Williams said as he walked through the tunnel.

Milton Williams walked through the tunnel and said, ‚ÄúNo. 1 offensive line can kiss my ass.‚Äù

‚Äî Mark Daniels (@ByMarkDaniels) January 25, 2026

Williams didn't record a sack on Sunday, but the Patriots sacked Jarrett Stidham three times, and the former Eagles defensive lineman was one of two New England defenders to record multiple quarterback hits in the win.

The Broncos' offensive line was ranked No. 1 in the NFL by Pro Football Focus at the end of the regular season. Tackle Garett Bolles and guard Quinn Meinerz both earned First-Team All-Pro selections, and the return of center Luke Wattenberg was expected to solidify the unit on Sunday.

Denver allowed two fewer sacks than New England, but Williams and the Patriots had the last laugh after shutting the Broncos out in the second half to capture an AFC championship on the road.

Earlier in the week, Williams rubbed some Broncos fans the wrong way when he was asked what he knew about Stidham.

"I ain't gonna lie, nothing. We're gonna watch the tape on him and figure out what he like to do. But no. They didn't like him over the Bo, so," Williams said.

Some interpreted Williams' response as simple honesty, as the Patriots had never had a reason to prepare for Stidham before Nix's injury, but others saw the comment as an underestimation of the Broncos' backup quarterback.

If Denver interpreted Williams' remarks as bulletin board material, it didn't make much of a difference in the end.

How weather negatively impacted AFC championship game

title: Reaction to Patriots winning AFC title and returning to Super Bowl for first time since end of Brady-Belichick era
description: In his first season as head coach of the New England Patriots, head coach Mike Vrabel has the franchise back in the Super Bowl, looking to win its seventh Vince Lombardi trophy.
fullText:

Like anything the Patriots do, there are plenty of opinions on their win, ranging from those within the game and watching from the outside.

New England defeated the Denver Broncos in a close defensive game affected by bad weather, 10-7 in the AFC championship game on Sunday. It wasn‚Äôt a masterclass by any means, but the Patriots got the win on the road in Denver despite quarterback Drake Maye passing for just 86 yards and being sacked five times.

Former Pittsburgh Steelers head coach Bill Cowher summed it up nicely with his reaction on the CBS broadcast following the game.

title: Cardi B reacts to Patriots' AFC Championship win over Broncos
description: How Cardi B reacted to the Patriots defeating the Broncos and punching their ticket to Super Bowl LX.
fullText:
Cardi B had a message after the New England Patriots' 10-7 win over the Denver Broncos in Sunday's AFC Championship Game.

"We're going to the Super Bowl. Let's go," Cardi B said after the game.

The Patriots survived a mostly defensive battle against the Broncos in the snow for the franchise's first playoff win at Mile High. Their defense held the Broncos to only 181 total yards and one touchdown in the game. The Broncos were also 4-of-14 on third downs and 0-of-1 on fourth downs.

All the Patriots could muster on offense was a six-yard touchdown run by Drake Maye and a field goal by rookie kicker Andy Borregales. Fortunately for them, it was enough.

title: Internet reacts as Patriots cap stunning season with Super Bowl trip
description: Mike Vrabel has led a remarkable turnaround for the Patriots in his first year as head coach.
fullText:
The New England Patriots have spent the last season engineering a remarkable turnaround, and on Sunday, they stunned the NFL by completing their journey back to the Super Bowl with an AFC Championship win over the Denver Broncos.

The Patriots captured a 10-7 win over the Broncos in a defensive struggle that turned out to be the second consecutive snow game for New England. And despite the challenging wintry environment and natural atmospheric challenges that accompany a trip to Empower Field at Mile High, the Patriots took care of business for their 17th victory of the season, returning to the Super Bowl for the first time since capturing Super Bowl LIII at the close of the 2018 season.

The Super Bowl appearance for the Patriots puts the cherry on top of a remarkable season that has gone better for the organization than any of their fans ‚Äì or really anyone who follows the league ‚Äì could have imagined. The Patriots are coming off back-to-back four-win seasons and are in their first season under the leadership of head coach Mike Vrabel, who previously captured three Super Bowls as a player with the franchise.

The Patriots will face the winner of the Los Angeles Rams and Seattle Seahawks in Super Bowl LX, as the NFC West Divisional Rivals battle in a rubber match on Sunday night in the NFC Championship Game after splitting their first two games of the year. Check out some of the reactions to their dramatic turnaround below.

fullText:
The 2025-26 NFL season is officially down to its final four and that means its Conference Championship schedule has arrived with teams vying for places in the Super Bowl.

While Super Bowl LX is two weeks away, the AFC and NFC Championship Games will have massive intrigue on Sunday.

The Denver Broncos, New England Patriots, Los Angeles Rams and Seattle Seahawks all over opportunities to punch their tickets to Santa Clara for the 60th edition of the NFL‚Äôs most important game.

Meanwhile, the NFC Championship Game sees the Rams and Seahawks clash for the third time this season. Both Sean McVay and Mike Macdonald‚Äôs teams have a win against their NFC West rival in 2025, including Seattle‚Äôs dramatic Week 16 overtime win.

In Denver, the number one seeded Broncos face the Patriots as a home underdog after Bo Nix‚Äôs brutal injury. The Broncos signal caller was ruled out after the team‚Äôs AFC Divisional Round thriller against the Buffalo Bills.

Drake Maye and the Patriots are now hopeful that they can go into Colorado and get back to the team‚Äôs first Super Bowl following the Tom Brady-Bill Belichick era.

title: Future Broncos: Building upon a Super Bowl contender
description: The Denver Broncos are in prime shape roster building-wise with the pre-draft circuit already kicking into gear.
fullText:
Later this afternoon, the Denver Broncos will host the New England Patriots in the AFC Championship game. The winner will represent the AFC in Super Bowl 60. Without question, it‚Äôs the biggest game the Broncos have played in a decade.

All of us certainly hope that Denver‚Äôs magical season continues. The shot at earning the franchise‚Äôs fourth Lombardi Trophy is the ultimate goal today. But if things go sideways, the Broncos will head to offseason mode figuring out what needs to be done in order to better prepare themselves next season.

Two avenues of pursuit will be available for Denver to accomplish that. The first will be free agency. The Broncos are slated to have around $27 million in cap space. However, simple moves and restructures could nearly double that amount if they so choose. I would expect the franchise to find a way to continue to build around Bo Nix and make some big investments, especially since there is no more dead money from Russell Wilson‚Äôs contract on the books for next season.

The next would be the draft. In fact, the pre-draft circuit is already in full swing. The East-West Shrine Bowl will take place on Tuesday with a contingent of Broncos scouts and evaluators present. Thereafter, personnel from across the league will travel to Mobile, Alabama for this year‚Äôs Senior Bowl that takes place on January 31st. Before you know it, the NFL Combine will be here in late February with the 2026 NFL Draft capping it all off at the end of April.

No matter the outcome of today‚Äôs game is, Broncos Country should be thrilled with how the team has performed this season. They have proven they are capable of being a Super Bowl contender. But guess what? They are in a great position to solidify their roster and have a chance to do the same in the coming years.

Championship Sunday. ü§©

IT'S GAMEDAY IN THE MILE HIGH CITY.#ClimbHigher x #NEvsDEN pic.twitter.com/4CYecR3Bkx

‚Äî Denver Broncos (@Broncos) January 25, 2026

The Broncos currently have five picks in the first four rounds. That puts them in an addition to address needs on their roster. If Defensive Coordinator Vance Joseph is hired away to be a Head Coach elsewhere, Denver would receive an additional third-round selection in both the 2026 and 2027 NFL Draft. There are still multiple coaching positions available. For a while, Joseph was considered the front-runner for the Arizona Cardinals‚Äô opening. Things seem to have quieted on that front, but you never know.

However, there is also a possibility that the Broncos consider wheeling and dealing for some extra selections by the time the draft rolls around. Pending the outcome of the games today, the Broncos will be slated to pick no higher than 29th in the ‚Äò26 NFL Draft. While they certainly may love a player who is on the board at that point in time, it would not be a surprise to see them trade out of the first round and acquire more Day 2 selections to address any glaring issues. General Manager George Paton has proven to be a wheeler-and-dealer when it comes to picks.

As of now, I‚Äôd like to see them focus on fortifying their trenches. Both the offensive and defensive lines could use some talent added to them. They have a great group of players already but given the age and contract status of several of their key starters‚ÄîI believe that should be a priority. Head Coach Sean Payton has always discussed the importance of building from the inside-out. I expect that is something we will see happen again this offseason.

The Broncos are clearly one of the best franchises in the NFL. They have a storied history and have accomplished a lot of great things. Very few teams across the league can say that much. Over the past several seasons, Denver has got back to their winning ways. There is no doubt players across the league are taking notice.

On top of that, their new ownership group is proving to be magnificent. They are doing whatever it takes to improve the team‚Äôs culture and performance. They are making significant investments across the board that other franchises simply aren‚Äôt capable of doing. We have witnessed new ownership and the front office being diligent in rewarding and extending in-house players who have performed at a high level and exemplify what it means to be a Bronco.

Those are just a few reasons I think Denver will be able to make some big splashes during free agency. They have certainly impressed this season. However, there are a few glaring areas [running back, inside linebacker, etc.] that need to be addressed for them to continue to be successful in the coming seasons. And those aforementioned position groups have a lot of talented players hitting the market in March.

What do you think, Broncos Country? Do you think Denver is geared up to have an eventful offseason? What are some moves you would like to see happen? Let me know in the comments section. (P.S., expect to see some Senior Bowl related Broncos content over the next week!)

title: Why Former Pro Bowler Sees ‚ÄòNo Ceiling‚Äô For Patriots‚Äô Drake Maye
description: It‚Äôs a scary thought for the NFL that Drake Maye hasn‚Äôt necessarily reached his full potential. Maye can conclude his second season with a Super Bowl appearance if the New England Patriots defeat the Denver Broncos on Sunday. The 23-year-old quarterback is also an MVP finalist after completing 72 percent of his passes for 4,394 [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
It‚Äôs a scary thought for the NFL that Drake Maye hasn‚Äôt necessarily reached his full potential.

Maye can conclude his second season with a Super Bowl appearance if the New England Patriots defeat the Denver Broncos on Sunday. The 23-year-old quarterback is also an MVP finalist after completing 72 percent of his passes for 4,394 yards and 31 touchdowns.

Capturing a Lombardi Trophy could help establish Maye as one of the league‚Äôs premier signal-callers. When asked how good he could become during CBS‚Äôs pre-game coverage of the AFC Championship Game, former Pro Bowl offensive lineman Kyle Long declared that the sky is the limit.

‚ÄúThere is no ceiling,‚Äù Long said. ‚ÄúFrom a physical standpoint, from a personality standpoint, from a toughness standpoint, he checks all the boxes.‚Äù

Maye endured an uneven rookie campaign for the 4-13 Patriots, but they‚Äôve reversed that record behind an improved roster. Long celebrated Maye‚Äôs maturation alongside a bolstered supporting cast and praised the North Carolina native‚Äôs humility.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs proved it all season long,‚Äù Long added. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs unbelievably accurate, but I think the thing that stands out the most ‚Ä¶ his personality. He‚Äôs got an ‚ÄòAw shucks‚Äô about him.‚Äù

Maye has been far from perfect this postseason, losing three of six fumbles and throwing an interception in each game. However, he also averaged 9.2 yards per pass attempt in a 16-3 win over the Los Angeles Chargers and tossed three touchdowns against the Houston Texans‚Äô No. 1-ranked defense in the AFC Divisional Round.

Surviving another stout Broncos defense could help Maye quickly stamp his place in Patriots lore and continue his ascension to superstardom.

How Patriots Would Make NFL History With AFC Championship Game Win Vs. Broncos

title: From Rams star to sommelier: Vince Ferragamo turned football lessons into life achievements
description: Vince Ferragamo was the first quarterback to lead the Rams to the Super Bowl, a feat that continues to be a source of pride and motivation for the longtime SoCal resident.
fullText:
The¬†sixth¬†in an¬†occasional series¬†of profiles on Southern California athletes who have flourished in their post-playing careers.

It‚Äôs been nearly four decades since Vince Ferragamo took his last NFL snap and most of his football exploits have been eclipsed by the passage of time.

The 509 passing yards he had in a 1982 loss to the Chicago Bears, most in an NFL game in 31 years? It‚Äôs been bettered 14 times. The club-record 30 passing touchdowns in 1980? That‚Äôs now seventh on the team‚Äôs single-season list.

But there‚Äôs one milestone no man, not even Father Time, can ever take away from Ferragamo. At the end of the 1979 season, he became the first quarterback to take the Rams to the Super Bowl.

The team has returned to the NFL championship game four times since then. A Rams‚Äô win over the Seattle Seahawks in Sunday's conference title game will keep alive Matthew Stafford‚Äôs chance to become the first quarterback in franchise history to win the Super Bowl twice.

Ferragamo, however, got them there first.

‚ÄúThere was just something so mystical about the whole thing,‚Äù says Ferragamo, who made his first NFL start that season.

He competes in a different arena now, managing a mortgage company and an eponymous real estate firm. He and his wife, Jodi, have helped raise millions for a variety of local charities and they also grow the grapes for their boutique wine label on 230 vines next to their home in central Orange County. The transition from the gridiron to the regular grind has been seamless.

‚ÄúFootball prepares you for life beyond football,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMore than anything it adds credibility to my work. They have to trust you. We‚Äôve built our whole company around that.‚Äù

Ferragamo‚Äôs football career also depended on earning trust. Although he was tall and blessed with a strong right arm, Ferragamo had to win over critics everywhere he played, beginning in high school where he had to convince his brother, the coach, he should start.

After two years at Cal, where he had to share playing time, Ferragamo transferred to Nebraska and became an All-American. Yet the Rams waited five picks and four rounds before selecting him in the 1977 draft, then handed him a clipboard and told him to find a spot on the bench.

‚ÄúThere was a lot of trials and tribulations. A lot of ups and downs,‚Äù Ferragamo said. ‚ÄúBut I think it teaches how to live life that way. Because every day you wake up with struggle.‚Äù

Yet for one glorious two-month stretch in the winter of 1979-80, the struggle was over and Ferragamo was arguably the best quarterback in the NFL, engineering one of the most improbable playoff runs in Rams history.

After starter Pat Haden was injured and rookie backup Jeff Rutledge proved ineffective, Ferragamo took over a team with a losing record. He was supposed to just finish out the season; instead, he carried the Rams to four consecutive victories.

He led the Rams to road playoff wins over Dallas and Tampa Bay, the first time in franchise history the Rams had won two playoff games in the same season.

‚ÄúHe began to show us that he had the arm to make the plays,‚Äù said Hall of Fame offensive tackle Jackie Slater, Ferragamo‚Äôs longtime teammate. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs when everybody began to rally to give the young guy as much support as we possibly could.

‚ÄúEverybody kicked it up a notch. And that‚Äôs what makes a good quarterback right? His leadership brings that out of you, makes you all a little bit better than you might have been without him.‚Äù

In the Super Bowl, played before nearly 104,000 people at the Rose Bowl ‚Äî still the largest crowd to attend a Super Bowl ‚Äî Ferragamo had the Rams leading heading into the fourth quarter before the Pittsburgh Steelers rallied to claim their fourth championship.

He won just one more playoff game, retiring seven years later following a career that took him to four cities and two countries ‚Äî but just one Super Bowl.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really have any regrets when I look back on my career,‚Äù Ferragamo, 71, said earlier this month, surrounded by football memorabilia in his second-floor corner office in Anaheim Hills. ‚ÄúIf everything was just carte blanche and just easy for you, it wouldn‚Äôt be worth living. So there‚Äôs always a challenge.

‚ÄúThe ups and downs, maybe that‚Äôs what kept me going.‚Äù

Ferragamo, the youngest of four children, grew up in Wilmington, which was a gritty, working-class city in the 1960s, much as it is today. His father, Vince Sr., a World War II veteran who dropped out of the school in the eighth grade, was street smart and tough, working his way up to union president of UAW local 923 at Ford‚Äôs sprawling Pico Rivera plant.

‚ÄúHe was a great role model for me,‚Äù Ferragamo remembered. ‚ÄúWe were the only Italian family in the neighborhood. It was, you know, tough, tough beginnings. It makes you desire and appreciate things and help others.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what football is,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúIf I can help my receiver look good, we all look good.‚Äù

And Ferragamo certainly looked good when he threw a football.

‚ÄúWhen he was about 14 years old, he‚Äôd go out in the front of the house and he‚Äôd throw the ball from one light pole to another. It‚Äôs a long way,‚Äù said Chris Ferragamo, Vince‚Äôs eldest brother and his coach and Banning High.

‚ÄúHe loved doing that kind of stuff. That‚Äôs how he started his throwing ability.‚Äù

Still, Chris, who would go on to win eight City Section titles at Banning, already had a quarterback when Vince joined the team as a sophomore, so he wasn‚Äôt about to hand him the starting job just because they were brothers.

‚ÄúPeople thought it was a cake walk. And it wasn‚Äôt,‚Äù Vince said.

‚ÄúHe never wanted to play me. The other coaches said, ‚ÄòHey, you‚Äôre crazy. You‚Äôve got to play him. He‚Äôs better than the other guys.'"

So Chris Ferragamo said he talked his returning quarterback into moving to wide receiver and Vince went on to become a high school all-American and the City Section player of the year, eventually earning induction into the California High School Football Hall of Fame.

That earned him a scholarship to Cal, where he played 22 games in two seasons, throwing nearly twice as many interceptions as touchdown passes. The Bears were placed on NCAA probation shortly after Ferragamo enrolled and when he found himself sharing time with Steve Bartkowski at quarterback, Ferragamo transferred to Nebraska and proved himself again, leading the Cornhuskers to a 10-2 record in 1975 and the No. 1 spot in the AP preseason poll a year later.

The critics weren‚Äôt convinced, so Ferragamo fell to the fourth round of the NFL draft where he was the 91st¬†player ‚Äî and fourth quarterback ‚Äî selected.

‚ÄúBasically he had to prove himself every place he went,‚Äù Chris Ferragamo said. ‚ÄúHe always did.‚Äù

Playing behind Haden and an aging Joe Namath, Ferragamo threw just 15 times as a rookie for a team that lost in the first round of the playoffs. A year later, as Haden's backup, he threw just a few more passes, the last in a one-sided loss to the Cowboys in the NFC championship game.

Ferragamo finally got his chance late in 1979. With the Rams struggling at 5-6 and Haden out because of an injured finger on his throwing hand, coach Ray Malavasi turned to Ferragamo, who lost just one of seven starts to get the Rams to their first Super Bowl.

‚ÄúWe knew Vince had a good, strong arm. And we knew he hadn‚Äôt played a lot of NFL games,‚Äù Slater said. ‚ÄúSo I think that everybody just kind of relaxed and said that we‚Äôve got to help this young guy be successful. Let‚Äôs just make sure we do our jobs and then hopefully our quarterback position won‚Äôt be a liability.

‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs kind of the way it worked out.‚Äù

The play that sealed Ferragamo‚Äôs status as the team‚Äôs new leader came with just over two minutes remaining in a first-round playoff game in Dallas. With the Rams trailing 19-14, Ferragamo threaded a pass to Billy Waddy, who was surrounded by six Cowboys. Waddy escaped the pack to score on the 50-yard play, Ferragamo‚Äôs third touchdown of the game and one he described as ‚Äúa spiritual pass, one that was guided from up above.‚Äù

The almighty apparently abandoned the Rams three weeks later when they twice blew leads in a 31-19 loss to Pittsburgh in the Super Bowl. Ferragamo had played well, throwing for 212 yards, although a late interception set up the Steelers‚Äô final touchdown.

Still, the Rams had established themselves as one of the top teams in the NFL. They had made seven consecutive playoff appearances and just two of their starters were over 30. With the 26-year-old Ferragamo taking over at quarterback, the team looked primed to become a perennial Super Bowl contender.

‚ÄúWe felt like it was going to be a good team for a long time,‚Äù Slater said.

Instead, the Rams won just five playoff games over the next 19 years and didn't return to the Super Bowl until the 1999 season, their fifth year in St. Louis.

‚ÄúThey dismantled the team after our Super Bowl run, which was unfortunate for the L.A. fans,‚Äù Ferragamo said. ‚ÄúThey had something in place that could have really been great.‚Äù

Ferragamo‚Äôs honeymoon was even shorter. After a spectacular post-Super Bowl season in which he set franchise records by throwing for 3,199 yards and 30 touchdowns, Ferragamo sought a raise from the $52,000 he earned in 1980, the lowest pay for a starting quarterback in the NFL. The Rams reportedly countered with a $250,000 offer during the season, then sweetened that by another $75,000 afterward.

But Ferragamo, angry that the team hadn‚Äôt given him a new deal after the Super Bowl, turned them down and jumped to the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, who offered a four-year deal worth about $2 million. That‚Äôs when things started to go off the rails.

A classic drop-back passer, Ferragamo wasn‚Äôt suited to the Canadian game, which put a premium on quarterback mobility. As a result, he threw just seven touchdown passes and was intercepted a league-high 25 times, eventually losing the starting job as Montreal stumbled to a 3-13 season.

Team owner Nelson Skalbania, an engineer and businessman from Vancouver, had an even worse year, first dissolving his company, then declaring bankruptcy, which forced him to return the team to league after one season. Ferragamo, whose contract was not guaranteed, was suddenly unemployed.

‚ÄúI went from the Super Bowl back to the bottom,‚Äù he said.

He also went back to the Rams, who signed him to a series of one-year contracts valued at approximately $300,000. Over the next three seasons he lost more games than he won and threw more interceptions than touchdown passes before moving on to Buffalo, which had the worst record in the NFL in his only season there.

His final three games came in a mop-up role for a Green Bay team that went 4-12 in 1986. At 32, his football career was over. But his second act was just beginning.

Jodi Scarpello was a freshman journalism major at Nebraska when a high school friend introduced her to a transfer student from California. The introduction wasn‚Äôt necessary since football was a religion in Lincoln and everyone knew about the handsome quarterback who had come over from Berkeley.

‚ÄúI knew what he was doing there,‚Äù Scarpello said. ‚ÄúI knew football when I met him.‚Äù

Three years later, after Ferragamo had graduated to the NFL, the couple married and a passion for football became something they shared.

‚ÄúI used to watch game film. We just watched at home on a reel-to-reel projector,‚Äù Jodi said. ‚ÄúI used to sit at games and call plays and people would think ‚Äòhow do you know that?‚Äô I‚Äôm a good student.‚Äù

Being the wife of a Super Bowl quarterback had other perks as well.

‚ÄúI met, at a charity banquet in Washington D.C., and had a conversation with Coretta Scott King,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe just talked about our children. But in my head I was thinking ‚ÄòOh my God, that is really cool!‚Äô

‚ÄúWe got to do a lot of traveling and that kind of stuff. It‚Äôs pretty amazing, some of the things we were able to do.‚Äù

There were also drawbacks. Unlike today, when wives and children are invited on to the field and sometimes into the locker room, in Ferragamo‚Äôs day teams maintained a distance between players and their families.

‚ÄúWhen Vince was playing, he left on Friday and I didn‚Äôt talk to him until he got back on Sunday night,‚Äù Jodi said. ‚ÄúHe got hurt one time in Buffalo and he‚Äôs rolling around on the ground. He keeps holding his arm. Maybe it‚Äôs his hand. I‚Äôm thinking, I‚Äôm not going to know.‚Äù

When it all came to an end after that dismal season in Green Bay, the Ferragamos still had more than half their lives ahead of them ‚Äî yet they were facing a life without football for the first time. Vince had never done anything¬†but¬†play football. Now he would have to learn to live without it.

So he called an audible and less than a year after retiring, he had a real estate license; eight years later he had his own real estate company. He would later add a mortgage fund.

‚ÄúWhen I retired, I said ‚Äòwhat am I going to do‚Äô,‚Äù remembered Ferragamo. ‚ÄúA lot of guys, when they get out of football they fall on hard times. But I was able to transfer into another field. I also did some investing while I was playing, which was smart. I had some money that could help get me through the transition.‚Äù

The couple, married 47 years, also had three children ‚Äî all daughters, Cara, Venessa and Jenna, which proved to be a blessing, their mother said, since none would feel pressured to follow their father into football.

‚ÄúIf they were playing now they could probably go play flag football,‚Äù Jodi Ferragamo said. ‚ÄúI think it was probably better not to have those kind of comparisons. And they‚Äôre all successful in their own way.‚Äù

But if selling real estate paid the bills, wine would become Ferragamo‚Äôs new passion.

With his football money he had purchased an acre lot in a largely equestrian community in central Orange Park Acres converted a horse corral on the property into a vineyard and became a self-taught winemaker, producing award-winning Italian Super Tuscan-style blends. He also became a certified sommelier and lecturer who teaches a community education course on the art and science of winemaking.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Italian,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI love all wines.‚Äù

The Ferragamos also created a foundation and have supported multiple causes, ranging from the Special Olympics, Boys & Girls Club and the Alzheimer‚Äôs Assn., to the Ronald McDonald House and the Orange Coast Medical Center, where a wing has been named in recognition of the Ferragamo Foundation‚Äôs contributions to the fight against breast cancer.

But football isn‚Äôt totally in the rear-view mirror. Ferragamo still attends a couple of Rams games each season, runs a flag football league for grade-school kids and co-hosts the weekly sports-talk show ‚ÄúOn Point Live‚Äù with Slater.

‚ÄúHe hasn‚Äôt changed. He‚Äôs still Vince,‚Äù said Slater, who has known Ferragamo since his rookie season. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a confident guy, smart guy. And he‚Äôs very competitive. So he‚Äôs the same guy.

‚ÄúKind of laid back. Family guy. Just loves the game of football.‚Äù

The ex-teammates remain close even though Slater says he almost got Ferragamo killed in the quarterback‚Äôs penultimate season with the Rams.

‚ÄúI got beat clean,‚Äù the hulking right tackle said. ‚ÄúMy old high school nemesis, Ben Williams from the Buffalo Bills, beat me and Vince was standing there about to throw and he just put his helmet right in the middle of his back. Oh, it was an ugly thing to see.

‚ÄúBlood comes flying out of his mouth. I don‚Äôt how he bloodied his mouth when he got hit in the back.‚Äù

That, Ferragamo admits, wasn‚Äôt exactly the most memorable moment of his career. Asked to chose the highlight of those 10 years, he leans back in his chair, folds him arms across his chest and thinks for a moment before settling on the obvious answer.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs probably the Super Bowl,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúand leading up to the Super Bowl.‚Äù

After all he was the first Rams quarterback to get that far, a distinction he‚Äôll own forever.

Get the best, most interesting and strangest stories of the day from the L.A. sports scene and beyond from our newsletter The Sports Report.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Column: Random thoughts on a budding Chicago sports bromance and other hot topics
description: Random thoughts while waiting on the release of the new Super Bowl commercials. The sight of Cubs star Pete-Crow Armstrong and Bears star Caleb Williams hanging out together at the Blackhawks and Bulls games was a nice way to portray Chicago as the biggest small town in America. Los Angeles has its Hollywood culture and New York is the media center of the world, but nowhere are the local ...
fullText:
Random thoughts while waiting on the release of the new Super Bowl commercials.

The sight of Cubs star Pete-Crow Armstrong and Bears star Caleb Williams hanging out together at the Blackhawks and Bulls games was a nice way to portray Chicago as the biggest small town in America. Los Angeles has its Hollywood culture and New York is the media center of the world, but nowhere are the local sports stars as big a deal as they are in Chicago.

It‚Äôs nothing new, of course. Chicago‚Äôs stars have always supported each other. When the Bears played at Wrigley Field, Bobby Hull was a season ticket holder, and Billy Williams used to get tickets for games from Bears receiver Dick Gordon.

The budding bromance of Crow-Armstrong and Williams should last a long time, or at least until the Cubs and Bears sign them to massive deals.

One of the primary requisites of the job of commissioner of a major sports league should be the ability to project strength. But the commissioners of the NFL, NBA, NHL and Major League Baseball are all weaklings, as evidenced by a report from The Athletic that Roger Goodell, Adam Silver, Gary Bettman and Rob Manfred will meet with President Donald Trump to help promote America 250, a celebration of the country‚Äôs 250th birthday.

While Trump‚Äôs jackboots instill fear in Minneapolis, Chicago and other American cities, and he embarrasses the country on the international stage, these four pretend leaders will be posing for photo-ops in the Oval Office and pretending all is right with the country. None of them has the courage to speak out against what‚Äôs happening in America.

Lucky for them, they‚Äôre only beholden to the billionaire owners of their league‚Äôs teams, not the average fans who support their respective sports.

ESPN‚Äôs Pat McAfee has always appealed to the lowest common denominator, so it‚Äôs no surprise the clueless commentator is taking on unidentified media members who point out his lame frat boy act, calling them ‚Äúfat ‚Ä¶ lazy nerds‚Äù on his TV show.

McAfee also tweeted that sports journalists ‚Äúhate what sports are for people (happiness). They hate what sports are for society (unifier) ‚Ä¶ they‚Äôre political journalists by nature who‚Äôve preyed on sports because they saw it as an easier path to ‚Äòmake it.‚Äô Their days are numbered ‚Ä¶ my show being broadcasted on ESPN 10 hours a week with ZERO creative say from any ‚Äòjournalism school‚Äô puppets is living proof of that.‚Äù

Actually, the audience of McAfee‚Äôs show is relatively tiny, or else it would be in a better time slot than in the early afternoon, when everyone else is working. He‚Äôs already wearing thin on college football fans, and sooner or later the ratings will slide and ESPN will pull the plug and send him off to UFC analysis, where he belongs.

Illinois is having another stellar season, thanks to a deep team led by freshman Keaton Wagler. The 11th-ranked Illini are 17-3 after Saturday‚Äôs 88-82 road win over Purdue and in contention for the Big Ten title.

And when the Illini are winning, coach Brad Underwood is at his most ornery, as when he recently sparred with an Illinois reporter who praised Tomislav Ivi≈°iƒá for a good game against Northwestern despite what he called an ‚Äúup-and-down season.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou guys say he‚Äôs been up and down,‚Äù Underwood shot back. ‚ÄúI just say his role changed. You guys create more damn narratives that are full of (bleep). That‚Äôs what he does. That‚Äôs why he‚Äôs been on draft boards. He‚Äôs big and can shoot the cover off of it. ‚Ä¶ No one has ever doubted Tommy.‚Äù

Love him or hate him, Underwood is never afraid to speak his mind.

Kudos to White Sox general manager Chris Getz for immediately spending the $20 million he saved by dumping Luis Robert Jr.‚Äôs contract, signing reliever Seranthony Dominguez to a two-year, $20 million deal. Now maybe he can move Grant Taylor into the rotation where he belongs.

Mike Berman was a professional and a hardworking sports reporter willing to work long hours at NBC-5. A Glenbrook North alumnus who grew up rooting for Chicago teams, he did his job for 10 years without calling attention to himself. His work spoke for itself.

Berman, who was let go by the station last week, deserved a better fate. Hopefully he winds up on another local station that will appreciate his work ethic.

Terry Boers, who died Friday at age 75, was remembered by most as a radio host and an original member of The Score. But he was also a great newspaperman. Boers and I competed on the Illini basketball beat for one season back in the early 1990s, when he was still at the Chicago Sun-Times. He was as good a beat writer as there was and handed me my lunch on many occasions.

Boers eventually found his way to radio, where he could put his brash personality into his job. He became a legend at WSCR-AM 670, along with the other originals such as Mike North, Tom Shaer and Dan McNeil. There will never be another quite like Boers, which is why his death has brought so many tributes from colleagues.

Cubs manager Craig Counsell is a Green Bay Packers fan, but he assured the media he is not a Bears hater. ‚ÄúLook, I grew up a Packers fan for sure,‚Äù he said before the Cubs Convention. ‚ÄúThe Bears have struggled for a while, and so when a team hasn‚Äôt done well for a whole and starts to do well, you see what it does to a city. You feel it. That part of me knows what it‚Äôs doing for the city, and you root for that a little bit.‚Äù

Asked who would be booed 

It‚Äôs a tough call, but my guess is Counsell is still Public Enemy No. 1 among cheeseheads.

title: NFL playoffs: How to watch, stream AFC, NFC Championship Games
description: The Patriots and Broncos and Rams and Seahawks play Sunday to determine the Super Bowl. Here is how to watch both games.
fullText:
There are four teams remaining in the NFL playoffs, and after today, we will know who will play in Super Bowl LX in Levi's Stadium in two weeks.

The AFC and NFC Championship Games are today. In one, the No. 1 seed Denver Broncos, playing without starting quarterback Bo Nix as he suffered a fractured ankle in the Broncos' overtime win over the Buffalo Bills last week, host the favored New England Patriots.

The NFC Championship Game is all about the NFC West, as the No. 1 seed Seattle Seahawks host the Los Angeles Rams.

If you are planning on watching those games, here is the info you need to know.

Game: No. 2 New England Patriots at No. 1 Denver Broncos

Stadium: Empower Field at Mile High, Denver, Colorado

Kickoff: 3 p.m. ET (1 p.m. Arizona time)

Broadcast team: Jim Nantz, Tony Romo

Game: No. 5 Los Angeles Rams at No. 1 Seattle Seahawks

Stadium: Lumen Field, Seattle, Washington

Kickoff: 6:30 p.m. ET (4:30 p.m. Arizona time

Broadcast team: Kevin Burkhardt, Tom Brady

title: NFL play-off predictions - who will make the Super Bowl?
description: See who BBC Sport's panel of experts have picked out to make Super Bowl 60 from Sunday's Championship games, and make your selections.
fullText:
It's Championship Sunday with one final hurdle to overcome on the road to Super Bowl 60, but who will make it through to Santa Clara?

The big story is the Denver Broncos having to play back-up quarterback Jarrett Stidham, the first man to start a Championship game without throwing a single pass for two seasons.

Can a home crowd and the Broncos defence help Stidham go from beanchwarmer to Super Bowl starter or will Drake Maye's New England Patriots prove too strong?

In the NFC, the Seattle Seahawks host the Los Angeles Rams for their third meeting of the season - there's been almost nothing between them in their two previous thrilling games.

We have a panel of experts to try to pick the winners - BBC Sport's Hugh Ferris, host of The Whole 10 Yards, BBC Radio 5 Live's Rob Staton and BBC Sport journalist Paul Higham.

title: Trump will not attend Super Bowl because it‚Äôs ‚Äôtoo far away,‚Äô he tells NY Post
Micah's predictions for USC stars on NFL Championship Sunday
description: Sam Darnold can make USC history. Other Trojans will play huge roles as they all try to make the Super Bowl
fullText:
We are one week closer to the conclusion of the NFL playoffs. This weekend will determine which two teams will make it to the Super Bowl. In both games, the former USC Trojans will play a huge factor and have their fingerprints all over games with the Super Bowl up for grabs. Sam Darnold not only has his legacy on the line, but also a chance to represent his alma mater for the first time on the NFL's biggest stage.

Here are my predictions for championship weekend in the NFL:

Sam Darnold and the Seahawks will enter the biggest game in recent memory for the former NFC juggernaut. This time around, they enter with a defense similar to the Legion of Boom but an offense that is more well-rounded. Seattle has looked miles ahead of the other playoff teams left. I think the Rams will give them a challenge and this game will come down to the last drive, but Seattle has proven themselves to be the better team between the two teams in this matchup. They can blowout teams, they can win close, low-score games, and they can win shootouts. I think this game, Sam Darnold, and the Seahawks offense will have to be at its best, but I think Darnold will deliver the best quarterback performance in this matchup. Seattle will move on and represent the NFC in the Super Bowl.

Many might gift wrap this win to the Patriots with Bo Nix being out for the rest of the season, but I disagree. I think the Patriots come out on top, but they will have to work for this game. The Broncos' defense will need former USC Trojan Talanoa Hufanga to fly around and make plays all day. The Patriots' offense has struggled to keep Drake Maye upright in each of their playoff games. Maye has been sacked 5 times. That is where the Broncos' defense specializes. Their defensive line can get after their quarterback like no other. The Broncos' defense will keep them in this game; it will come down to whether or not he can put together his best Nick Foles impression. I think he will play well, but not well enough to win this football game. I think he will come up short late and throw a costly interception, and Drake Maye and Mike Vrabel will iron out this victory in a low-scoring defensive battle.

I think Sam Darnold saves his biggest performance for the game right before the Super Bowl. Darnold squeaked by Stafford and the Rams in the last meeting between the two teams in an overtime win. Darnold will have to play exactly like he did down the stretch in that game to get the victory in this one. I think Darnold reaches 300 yards through the air, and he and Jaxon Smith-Njigba light up the Rams' secondary. This secondary has given up their fair share of big games to their opponent. This game will be no different. Jaxon Smith-Njigba will have over 100 yards receiving, and he will connect with Sam Darnold for two touchdowns in this game. I think Darnold and Jaxon Smith-Njigba have the two biggest performances in the NFC Championship game.

In the AFC, I think pass rusher Nik Bonitto has the most dominant performance. The Patriots have given up 5 sacks in each of their playoff games. In the last game versus the Texans, Danielle Hunter and Will Anderson Jr. combined for 5 sacks. Bonitto this season had 14 sacks. I think he will have 3 sacks in this game and disrupt Drake Maye all game long.

I think defensive tackle Milton Williams will also have himself a big game and disrupt the Broncos on the other end. Williams has been a huge reason for the Patriots' defensive turnaround, and he was great all regular season long. He creates pressure from the interior with the best of them, and he is a great run stopper. I think he will lead this Patriots defensive line to make the Broncos one-dimensional and take out their run game. Williams will also lead the Patriots in sacks with two. Verus the Chargers, Williams had two sacks, and against the Texans, he was an irritant all game long, forcing the pick 6 that took the momentum away from Houston initially. I think Milton Williams will use all of that to have his best playoff game with the Patriots and help send his team to the Super Bowl.

My Super Bowl matchup prediction is the New England Patriots taking on the Seattle Seahawks. The Patriots have had quite the Super Bowl run vs tough defenses, but they still will not be prepared for the Seahawks' defense. Mike Macdonald and the Seahawks defense will make it a tough day for young star quarterback Drake Maye. I think his age and inexperience will come back to bite him in this match. I think Rashid Shaheed will pay homage to Devin Hester and take the opening kickoff back for a touchdown, setting the tone for the entire game. I think Darnold will not have to do much to be the top quarterback on the field, but he still will put up a respectable performance. Seattle will play their last complete performance of the season, getting their Super Bowl victory. Darnold will look to be greedy and not just settle for being the first Trojan quarterback to start in the Super Bowl, but he will also become the first Trojan quarterback to win a Super Bowl.

This article originally appeared on Trojans Wire: Predictions for USC on championship weekend in NFL playoffs

title: Falcons listed as best landing spot for Super Bowl-winning quarterback
description: Atlanta could look to retool its quarterback depth.
fullText:
Falcons listed as best landing spot for Super Bowl-winning quarterback originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The quarterback position in Atlanta is a bit up in the air right now. Michael Penix is the team‚Äôs QB of the future, but he might not be ready for the start of the 2026 season after suffering a torn ACL in November.

The Falcons also have veteran Kirk Cousins on the roster, but they could look to release him in a cost-cutting move in the coming weeks.

If they do move on from Cousins, they would need to identify another quarterback who could potentially serve as a starter in Penix‚Äôs absence and then shift to a reserve role. That‚Äôs where Joe Flacco could come in.

In a recent article, Kristopher Knox of Bleacher Report¬†listed the Falcons as the best landing spot for Flacco, citing his relationship with new head coach Kevin Stefanski and ability to effectively operate as a fill-in starter.

‚ÄúIf the Falcons don't retain Cousins as veteran insurance, Flacco would be the perfect alternative. Stefanski and Flacco helped take the Browns to the playoffs in 2023, and the pair could likely get Atlanta off to a hot start if Penix isn't ready to go when the season opens,‚Äù Knox wrote.

‚ÄúThe Falcons don't quite have the receiving corps that the Bengals have, but Flacco would probably find success alongside Drake London, Bijan Robinson, and Kyle Pitts‚Äîassuming Pitts is retained in free agency.‚Äù

Flacco would certainly be cheaper than Cousins, and even thought he‚Äôs 41 years old, he‚Äôs demonstrated that he can still run an offense at a high level.

In 13 games ‚Äì and 10 starts ‚Äì split between Cleveland and Cincinnati last season, Flacco threw for 2,479 yards and 13 touchdowns, compared to just four interceptions.

First, the Falcons have to figure out what they want to do with Cousins. If they do decide to move on from him, Flacco could actually make a lot of sense as a replacement.

title: Fact Check: Don't fall for rumor Jalen Hurts established Renee Good Hope Scholarship Fund
description: According to the rumor, the NFL's 2025 Super Bowl MVP donated $300,000 of his own money as a way of kick-starting the special fund.
fullText:
Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Jalen Hurts established the Renee Good Hope Scholarship Fund ‚Äî in honor of the woman fatally shot by an ICE agent in Minneapolis in January 2026 ‚Äîand contributed $300,000.

In January 2026, online users shared a rumor claiming Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Jalen Hurts established the Renee Good Hope Scholarship Fund. Users' posts claimed the NFL's Super Bowl LIX MVP kickstarted the fund himself, contributing $300,000 of his own money.

The purported scholarship fund referenced Renee Good, a 37-year-old Minneapolis resident shot fatally shot on Jan. 7 by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer Jonathan Ross.

For example, on Jan. 20, a user managing the NFL Pulse Facebook page posted (archived) an image collage of three pictures allegedly showing Hurts hugging Good's 6-year-old son on a football field, Good holding her son in front of a body of water and Hurts walking inside a football stadium. The post's text claimed Good's killing inspired Hurts to launch the Renee Good Hope Scholarship Fund, including the $300,000 contribution.

In short, the rumor was false. One or more users fabricated and promoted the claim with the help of images and text generated with artificial-intelligence tools.

Snopes contacted a manager of the NFL Pulse Facebook page to ask about the fictional stories and AI-generated content displayed on the feed, as well as the Philadelphia Eagles to request an official statement, and will update this story if we receive more information.

The NFL Pulse Facebook post (archived) ‚Äî as well as other Facebook posts sharing the same rumor ‚Äî featured links leading to advertisement-filled articles hosted on WordPress blogs. The users owning those blogs earned revenue based on the combination of advertising and made-up stories. The NFL Pulse post redirected to an article on on such untrustworthy website.

Searches of Bing, DuckDuckGo and Google found no news media outlets reporting about Hurts establishing a scholarship fund in Good's name. A Yahoo search did, however, mistakenly produce an AI-generated answer wrongly confirming the rumor as true. Outlets would have widely reported on the story involving Hurts and Good, had it truly occurred.

Regarding the fake, AI-generated photo of Hurts holding Good's son, the most evident sign of AI ‚Äî¬†aside from the misspelling of "Eagles" as "Eaglees" ‚Äî was the reality that sports and standard news outlets would have very widely publicized the moment, had the meeting between the quarterback and young boy truly taken place.

The NFL Pulse Facebook post's text, presented in its entirety later in this article, featured over-dramatic wording common with AI tools. For example, one part of the post read, "This was not charity for attention. It was an act of remembrance, of dignity, and of deep human empathy ‚Äî a reminder that even in the aftermath of violence and loss, compassion can still speak louder than silence." Additionally, the idea that individuals or teams aiming to rapidly produce inauthentic content for ad revenue would carefully, slowly and manually write text for their articles simply does not square with reality.

The person or people who authored the story about Hurts and Good fabricated the entire claim as one of hundreds of inspirational tales that depicted celebrities and athletes performing inspiring acts of kindness. Such stories resemble glurge, which Dictionary.com defines as stories "that are supposed to be true and uplifting, but which are often fabricated and sentimental."

For readers interested in the story told in the NFL Pulse Facebook post, the post presented the made-up tale as follows:

Jalen Hurts has officially established The Renee Good Hope Scholarship Fund, personally committing an initial $300,000 donation to honor the life of Renee Nicole Good ‚Äî a mother whose story ended in tragedy after she was killed in Minneapolis, a loss that left an entire community grieving.

But this gesture goes far beyond a financial contribution.

Jalen Hurts founded the scholarship fund himself to ensure that Renee's 6-year-old son will receive full educational support from elementary school through college ‚Äî including tuition, books, tutoring, and opportunities for personal development. Alongside the financial commitment, Jalen also dedicated his voice, his platform, and his heart to a child now facing a world without his mother.

This was not charity for attention. It was an act of remembrance, of dignity, and of deep human empathy ‚Äî a reminder that even in the aftermath of violence and loss, compassion can still speak louder than silence.

Across the nation, many were moved not by the amount of money pledged, but by the meaning behind Jalen's decision: a promise that Renee Nicole Good's life mattered, and that her son's future will be protected, supported, and filled with hope.

For further reading, we previously reported about the time tech billionaire Elon Musk deleted a post supporting the Eagles supporting the Eagles after they lost the 2023 Super Bowl LVII.

"GLURGE Definition & Meaning." Dictionary.com, https://www.dictionary.com/browse/glurge.

Huberman, Bond, and David Emery. "Snopestionary: What Does 'Glurge' Mean?" Snopes, 21 Aug. 2021, https://www.snopes.com//articles/363643/what-does-glurge-mean/.

title: Why Rams will halt my old friend's journey to brink of Super Bowl
description: NFL analyst Phoebe Schecter explains why she feels Los Angeles will deny Seattle's British coach a spot in Super Bowl 60, and reacts to Buffalo's coaching change.
fullText:
We've reached the Conference Championships. One more win and you're in the Super Bowl.

Both these match-ups on Sunday are so hard to call, but in particular the Los Angeles Rams at the Seattle Seahawks.

They're divisional rivals in the NFC West so have already played each other twice this season. They're 1-1 having each won at home - and just look at those games.

The Rams won the first by two points and the Seahawks won the second by one point in overtime, so the combined score is 58-57 and total yards 830-829, both in favour of the Rams.

title: Super Bowl odds: Are Los Angeles Rams the favorite?
description: Coach Sean McVay and the Los Angeles Rams are one victory away from another Super Bowl appearance.
fullText:
Coach Sean McVay and the Los Angeles Rams are one victory away from another Super Bowl appearance.

The Rams have made five Super Bowl appearances overall, including two under McVay to cap the 2018 and 2021 seasons. The franchise has a 2-3 overall record in the big game, its most recent win coming in Super Bowl 56 in February 2022.

Quarterback Matthew Stafford and the Rams‚Äô offense will have to overcome a strong Seattle defense on Sunday. The Seahawks ranked third in yards allowed with 236 during the regular season.

Stafford and the offense produced league-highs in total yards per game (394.6) and points per game (30.5) during the regular season.

The Rams have the second-best odds to win the Super Bowl, according to BetMGM.

Super Bowl odds as of Thursday, Jan. 22

The Rams will play the Seattle Seahawks in the NFC Championship Game on Sunday, Jan. 25 at 6:30 p.m. ET (3:30 p.m. PT).

title: He has not thrown an NFL pass for two years - now he is one game from the Super Bowl
description: When the Denver Broncos host the New England Patriots on Sunday in the AFC Championship game, it will be with a back-up quarterback who has not thrown an NFL pass for two seasons.
fullText:
In the midst of Saturday's play-off celebrations, the "most unusual" NFL season in years got even stranger.

The Denver Broncos had just beaten the Buffalo Bills to move within one win of the Super Bowl when head coach Sean Payton revealed that, on one of the last plays of the game, quarterback Bo Nix suffered a broken ankle.

In his second year in the NFL, Nix has led Denver to the AFC's top seed and the AFC Championship game, but he has now been denied a shot at Super Bowl glory.

Then as the NFL world reacted to that cruel blow, it dawned who would be tasked with keeping the Broncos' championship hopes alive: Jarrett Stidham.

Denver's back-up is set to become the first quarterback to make his first start of the season in the Conference Championships since Roger Staubach in 1972.

It got stranger still on Sunday as the New England Patriots, the team that drafted Stidham in 2019, booked a trip to Denver this weekend.

So now the man once seen as the heir apparent to Tom Brady will face the legendary quarterback's eventual successor, Drake Maye, for a place in Super Bowl 60.

title: Analyst gives 2 reasons for Broncos Super Bowl hope vs. Patriots
description: This won't be a walk in the park for New England.
fullText:
Analyst gives 2 reasons for Broncos Super Bowl hope vs. Patriots originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

For most, when it was revealed by Denver Broncos head coach Sean Payton that Bo Nix was done for the year after breaking a bone in his foot against the Buffalo Bills, Denver's Super Bowl hopes went with him.

Granted, there is merit to that thought, given how stout the New England Patriots' defense is.

But all is not lost. There is hope.

However, you have to look really hard to find it.

Which is what Sports Illustrated's Gilberto Manzano has done.

"There‚Äôs too much focus on Bo Nix not being available due to injury and not enough attention on the advantages that could come from having a stout defense and getting to call Mile High Stadium home," Manzano wrote.

"Those two reasons are why I‚Äôm confident the Broncos will hang with the Patriots, but Stidham is also no slouch.¬†Let‚Äôs not be so quick to punch the Patriots‚Äô ticket to Santa Clara for Super Bowl LX."

More:Bo Nix injury update: Broncos QB suffers season-ending ankle fracture in win over Bills

Of course he can, but will he? I have my doubts.

But as Manzano pointed out, having one of the best defenses in your back pocket, plus playing at home, this will be a game that Stidham won't have to hang 30 points to win.

Just 17 might be enough to do it. And Stidham can do that, right?

With J.K. Dobbins back at practice, albeit in a limited capacity, leaning on the run game could be the avenue Payton goes down.

Are the Broncos a chance of an upset? Absolutely.
